title: RL34377
content: Congress has passed legislation over the past six decades to regulate lobbyist contact with Members of Congress. The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 repealed the initial provisions from the Legislative Reorganization Act of 1946 and established detailed reporting thresholds. Amendments in 1998 and 2007 further enhanced disclosure and reporting requirements for lobbyists and lobbying firms. The LDA of 1995 provided specific thresholds and definitions for lobbyists, lobbying activities, and lobbying contacts. The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 replaced previous lobbying disclosure laws to create a single statute covering all professional lobbyists. It streamlined disclosure requirements, mandated registration and regular reporting by lobbyists, and improved enforcement mechanisms. Amendments in 1998 clarified definitions and expanded coverage to include lobbying activities limited by the Internal Revenue Code. The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 was amended in 1998 to include lobbying activities limited by the Internal Revenue Code. The need for change was explained by the Senate Committee on Governmental Affairs due to minor problems with the language of the statute. The Honest Leadership and Open Government Act of 2007 mandated additional disclosures. The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995, amended in 1998 and by the Honest Leadership and Open Government Act of 2007, requires lobbyists to register, file financial records, and quarterly reports with the Clerk of the House and the Secretary of the Senate. The Clerk and Secretary also provide guidance on registration and reporting requirements. The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995, amended in 1998 and by the Honest Leadership and Open Government Act of 2007, requires lobbyists to register, file financial records, and quarterly reports with the Clerk of the House and the Secretary of the Senate. The Clerk and Secretary provide guidance on registration and reporting requirements, develop common standards, rules, and procedures for compliance, review and verify registrations and reports, maintain filing systems, make information publicly available, retain records for at least 6 years, and compile information for each semi-annual period. The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995, amended in 1998 and by the Honest Leadership and Open Government Act of 2007, requires lobbyists to register, file financial records, and quarterly reports with the Clerk of the House and the Secretary of the Senate. The Clerk and Secretary are responsible for electronically registering lobbyists, collecting quarterly and semi-annual reports, making information publicly available, and notifying lobbyists of any noncompliance with the Act. The Clerk of the House and the Secretary of the Senate implement lobbyist registration and disclosure provisions under the Lobbying Disclosure Act. They use a single electronic filing system for lobbyists to register and transmit documents. They issue joint guidance to inform lobbyists and the public on their duties. The HLOGA amendments require lobbyists to file quarterly reports by specific deadlines and register within 45 days of their first lobbying contact. Electronic filing is now mandatory through a joint portal maintained by the Clerk and the Secretary. Prior to these amendments, electronic submission was not required under the LDA, with the Secretary of the Senate offering electronic filing options while the Clerk of the House did not. The HLOGA amended the LDA to make electronic filing mandatory, except in certain circumstances. The Clerk and Secretary created a single electronic registration system with user ID and password protocols. The website provides software applications for all filings and is compatible with Windows and Mac operating systems. Detailed instructions and filing requirements are available on the House and Senate lobbying disclosure websites. The Clerk and Secretary are responsible for maintaining the electronic filing system website, providing updated information, and notifying lobbyists of noncompliance. They review filings for accuracy and issue notices to non-compliant registrants, who have 60 days to respond before potential legal action. Columbia. 2 U.S.C. §1605(a) (3), (4), and (5), as amended by HLOGA Section 209, requires the Clerk and the Secretary to make registration and disclosure information publicly available for at least six years. This includes developing filing systems, making registrations and reports available for public inspection, and retaining them for a minimum of six years. The Clerk and the Secretary have established websites for public access to registration and disclosure information. The Clerk and the Secretary have established websites for public access to registration and disclosure documents. The Lobbying Disclosure Act Guidance states that reports will be delivered via the Internet. The guidance document, divided into 12 sections, is updated as needed and was last updated on January 31, 2017. The Clerk and the Secretary do not have the authority to write regulations or issue opinions on the law. The Clerk and the Secretary provide guidance on the Lobbying Disclosure Act, which is not enforceable as law. The guidance document is divided into 12 sections, with Section 1 providing background information and Section 3 defining key terms. The document was last updated on January 31, 2017. Section 3 of the guidance document adds the definition of "actively participates" from Section 207 of HLOGA. Section 4 explains the lobbying registration process, including who must register, when registrations are necessary, preparations for filing registrations, exceptions to lobbying contacts, the 20% activity threshold, and the relationship between activity and monetary thresholds. The monetary thresholds are updated periodically to reflect changes in the Consumer Price Index. The guidance also provides examples to illustrate the operation of the section for the lobbying community. Additionally, Section 5 outlines special circumstances that could affect lobbyist registration. Section 5 outlines special circumstances affecting lobbyist registration, including lobbying firms retained by contingent fees, registration by entities with subsidiaries or affiliates, mergers and acquisitions, registration for associations, coalitions, churches, and professional associations of elected officials. Section 6 explains quarterly reporting of lobbying activities, when reports are needed, how to complete disclosure forms LD-1 and LD-2, reporting firm income, and examples of material to include in reports. Section 7 of the quarterly report guidelines emphasizes the reporting requirements for organizations paying dues to other organizations for lobbying activities. It also introduces a specific reporting code for lobbying on tariff bills and reminds new lobbyists to disclose previous executive or legislative positions held within 20 years. Additionally, it clarifies that disclosing foreign interests is mandatory regardless of contributions made during the reporting period. Section 7 discusses the need for semiannual reports, who is required to file form LD-203, the required contents of the report, and the importance of retaining appropriate documentation. Section 8 explains the termination procedure for lobbyists and clients, while Section 9 briefly explains the relationship between the Lobbying Disclosure Act and other statutes. Section 10 of the Lobbying Disclosure Act (LDA) requires registrations and reports to be made available to the public online. Section 11 mandates a review process to ensure accuracy and completeness of filings. Section 12 outlines penalties for filing incorrect information. The Clerk of the House and the Secretary of the Senate oversee compliance with these requirements. The Clerk and the Secretary established a contributions reporting system and website under 2 U.S.C. §1604(e) for lobbying organizations and lobbyists to register electronically. The website includes a help feature for navigating the new form.
